messageBody:
> Anshuman wrote:
>
> Hi !,
>
> In JDK 1.4.0 Beta 2 verion, assert is a keyword. Has any one
> looked into this ? Is there any proposed changes for the JUnit assert
> method ? How will a code for the unit testing written using JUnit be
> compatible with the JDK1.4 version ?

I'm offering this response to be added to the new FAQ, since this
question comes up about once a week. Jim, are you maintaining the FAQ?

Q: In Java 1.4, 'assert' is a keyword. Won't this conflict with JUnit's
assert() method? If so, what can be done about it?

A: JUnit 3.7 deprecates assert() and replaces it with assertTrue(),
which works exactly the same way. Simply upgrade your JUnit to 3.7 and
change all assert() calls in your existing tests to assertTrue().

If you have Perl and a Unix shell (or a Unix-like shell in Windows, such
as Cygwin or MKS Toolkit), this can be accomplished with a global
replacement at the command line.

Simply go to the top of your Java source code directory and run the
following command:

$ find . -name \*.java | xargs perl -i.bak -p -e
's/assert\(/assertTrue\(/g;'

This will search every Java source file in your tree for the string
"assert(" and replace it with "assertTrue(". The open parentheses is
included to avoid accidentally changing instances of the word "assert"
that aren't JUnit methods. Copies of your original source files are
renamed with the .bak suffix, so if something goes wrong you can always
undo your work.

If you are in a Windows environment and don't have these sorts of Unix
shell tools, Cygwin <http://www.redhat.com/software/tools/cygwin/> is
freely available under GPL, and includes the find and xargs commands as
well as Perl. Alternately, if you have a lot of time on your hands and
never make mistakes, you could manually edit all your tests with a GUI
editor in your IDE.
